article.description: Ben Gordon and Connecticut  put forth a completely different effort than their last meeting with Massachusetts.
article.headline: Gordon sinks 7 of 8 3s, scores 34 points
article.story: HARTFORD, Conn. (AP) -- Ben Gordon's teammates have seen it all before. The roundhouse dunk or a rim-rattling slam to finish a break or a cool 3-pointer with a man in his face, that's just Ben being Ben, the Connecticut Huskies say. On Tuesday night, Massachusetts got an eyeful, too. The junior guard scored 34 points, going 7-of-8 from 3-point range, to lead the top-ranked Huskies to an easy 91-67 victory over their border rival. "We see that every single day," point guard Taliek Brown said. "The things he does don't even amaze us." The annual so-called "U-Game" was all UConn. Unlike last year when UConn rallied to win from a 25-point deficit with under 19 minutes to play, the Huskies wasted no time controlling this game. Gordon opened the game with 3-pointer to kick off an 11-0 run. He had 12 of UConn's first 25 points midway through the half, hitting from behind a screen or finishing with a flash on the break. "I usually just come out the day before and before the game and just get the shots up that I'm going to take in the game," Gordon said. "That way I get my rhythm." Gordon and the Huskies found their rhythm early with transition offense and a smothering press. But a total of 40 fouls made for a choppy finish and didn't sit well with UConn coach Jim Calhoun. "I thought we were penalized because we were bigger, stronger and better," Calhoun said. "I want our kids to use the 40 minutes to get better, and I didn't think we were able to do that in the second half because we were penalized." UConn center Emeka Okafor, consistently double-teamed, played just 20 minutes before fouling out and was held to six points, 12 below his average. But the junior center still grabbed 10 rebounds and had five of UConn's 10 blocks. With Okafor's time limited, freshman Charlie Villanueva stepped up in the post with a career-high 19 points, most off offensive rebounds. He also had 10 rebounds for UConn's dominant post game. "I'm willing to do whatever it takes to win the game," Villanueva said. "Emeka motivated me because of his absence in the first half, I had to step up." The Huskies (10-1) lead the series 68-38 and have owned the Minutemen the past several years, winning the last 13 meetings and 21 of 22. UMass (5-5), led by Jeff Viggiano's career-high 22 points, had its three-game winning streak snapped. The Huskies outrebounded UMass 48-27 and scored 27 points off offensive rebounds. The Huskies dominated inside early and in the first five minutes had outrebounded the Minutemen 8-0. The defensive rebounding fueled UConn's transition game and the Huskies led 55-29 at halftime. The second half was more of the same as it started with a 3 by Gordon and a 9-0 run. Gordon finished three points shy of his career high set Nov. 19, in a 93-79 win over Nevada. Brown matched a career-high with 12 assists for UConn. UMass coach Steve Lappas was disappointed his team was unable to wait out the uptempo Huskies by taking quick shots once they broke the press. "That's the worst thing you can do is play a tempo game against Connecticut," Lappas said. "That set a bad tone right there." Rashaun Freeman and Anthony Anderson each scored 15 points for UMass. The game wraps up a six-game homestand for UConn, which plays at Rice on Friday in a homecoming of sorts for Okafor, who grew up in Houston. Gordon said he's ready to hit the road. "It's good to go in it like this with a lot of confidence. We just have to bring our same mentality," Gordon said. "It's pretty fun to go out and beat a team in their own gym."
